blocks.title: Welcome to MapStudy
blocks.ask: This is what a typical MapStudy page looks like. The left side of the window houses a map, either interactive or static as configured by the survey designer. On the right side, the participant is presented with survey questions, which may include descriptive text and other media elements.

blocks.title: Full Questions Page
blocks.ask: The window may be configured to hide the map section and only show the questions section, but not vice-versa. It also includes a static header containing a customized title and branding, and a footer with the survey designerâ€™s contact information and social media links.
Surveys often start with non-map pages, and use text inputs such as the one below to request information or consent from participants.

blocks.title: Map Library Types
blocks.ask: The library module determines which web mapping software or service will be used to render the map. The current options allow a tile-based interactive web map using the Leaflet code library, a static map image rendered directly on the page, or an HTML iframe element for rendering additional multimedia content.
On the left is an example of an interactive web map using the Leaflet library.

blocks.title: Library Type: Image
blocks.ask: Here's an example of a static, non-interactive map image.

blocks.title: Library Type: iframe
blocks.ask: And here's an example of a map rendered from an iframe.

blocks.title: Library Type: iframe
blocks.ask: The iframe library type can also be used to render non-map multimedia elements.

blocks.title: Base Layers
blocks.ask: You can include base layers from various sources, including tile services from Stamen and ESRI. The underlay interaction allows users to toggle between base layers.

blocks.title: Data Layers (Set 1)
blocks.ask: For Leaflet interactive maps, users can also add data layers to be displayed on the map. These layers are displayed atop the visible base layer, and may be displayed simultaneously or configured to allow participants to turn each one on and off using the overlay interaction operator.

blocks.title: Sets
blocks.ask: Pages may have multiple sets and blocks of questions. This is the second block of the first set for this page. Click 'Next' to progress to the next set for this page.

blocks.title: Data Layers (Set 2)
blocks.ask: Each data layer requires a source of vector data stored in GeoJSON, TopoJSON, or PostGIS table format, as well as an expressed attribute that specifies the attribute to be visualized. The four layers on this map use the same GeoJSON, with data from the UN on GDP growth per capita, but use different techniques.

blocks.title: Technique Types
blocks.ask:
Mapstudy includes support for five data layer techniques:
  • choropleth
  • proportional symbol
  • dot density
  • heat
  • isoline(for continuous data, not included here)

blocks.title: Data Classification
blocks.ask:
For choropleth and proportional symbol layers, a classification method must also be specified for purposes of binning the data. Available classification methods:
  • quantile
  • equal interval
  • natural breaks
  • unlassed
  • user defined
If provided, participants can change the classification method using the resymbolize interaction operator.

blocks.title: Interactions
blocks.ask: Each interactive map page must include a module item enabling various interaction operators, functions allowing the participant to manipulate the map. Each interaction may be configured to include a toggle switch allowing participants to manually enable or disable the interaction.

Available interaction operators include:
  • Zoom
  • Pan
  • Retrieve
  • Overlay
  • Underlay
  • Search
  • Filter
  • Reexpress
  • Resymbolize
  • Reset
The map on the left includes all availble interaction operators, which are described in detail in the full documentation.

blocks.title: Question Blocks
blocks.ask: Question blocks may consist of the following parts, including photos and videos:

blocks.title: Title
blocks.ask: The ask, an HTML string usually typically containing a survey question
blocks.description: The description, further context displayed in italic.

blocks.title: Input Types
blocks.ask: Question blocks may include a variety of user input types:

blocks.title: Further Resources
blocks.ask: To inspect and extend these examples, see the underlying code in the 'config' folder from this walkthrough's Github repo. Upload the zipped config to MapStudy's setup application or open manually in a text editor to edit for your own purposes. Full documentation is available here. Happy Mapping!
